text:
I'm Director of Content at Mio, have a freelance retainer elsewhere, and a couples of one-off projects on the go at any one time. I thrive this way! The additional one-offs are probably only working because of lockdown and spare time etc.

Workflow of others hasn't differed much as I am based in the UK and the rest of Mio is in the US. We've always worked mostly asynchronously; it's just a little more asynchronous now.

text: Hi all, this is really interesting. I was always assuming that it was just at the company I work for that we don't tie SEO and content marketing together and I thought that was because we'd just started out. But it seems to be quite common. To me it seems like wasted potential - or are there any significant strategic or business reasons why you wouldn't do it?

text: I've got a pillar post and 4 other blog posts that I want to turn into a downloadable ebook / PDF. Does anyone have a recommendation for converting multiple posts to one ebook?

elements.text: I've got a pillar post and 4 other blog posts that I want to turn into a downloadable ebook / PDF. Does anyone have a recommendation for converting multiple posts to one ebook?

text: Something I always try to do while repurposing blogs into an ebook: Condense it as much as possible and front load the important stuff.

text:
I'm a full time copywriter at a health + nutrition company and do side gigs on the weekends or evenings if a good one (or past client) comes my way. :slightly_smiling_face:

In terms of workflow... I have a 15mo, and it's a pandemic. So most of my day is spent on my day job unless I need to do a call for a current freelance project. Then I'll take an hour and readjust. My company was already remote before the pandemic so they're incredibly flexible with working hours.

As for workflow, I mainly work on freelance stuff on weekends or when my kid is asleep :slightly_smiling_face: I also _make sure_ that I don't take on too much... it's supposed to be a delicious little extra that keeps my freelance name out there, NOT an overwork, overstress sort of thing.

text:
Currently leading marketing at `<http://Soapboxhq.com|Soapboxhq.com>` and do freelance writing on the side as well.

In terms of workflow, since leading the marketing function, I’ve minimized the amount of freelance work I’m taking on. Otherwise, I do my regular 9-5 and have typical turnaround for my freelance clients within a week? Generally I just do it at night or on the weekend, whenever I’m free and in the right headspace.

text: Hi everyone! Was wondering if anyone has any conversion rate benchmark reports for websites based on the "type of page"? I.e. Homepage vs. pricing page vs. industry page, etc. Trying to figure out how our website stacks up against others!

elements.text: Hi everyone! Was wondering if anyone has any conversion rate benchmark reports for websites based on the "type of page"? I.e. Homepage vs. pricing page vs. industry page, etc. Trying to figure out how our website stacks up against others!

text: Hi <@UUKNSLX9P>, this may not be the advice you're after, but my mentor always reminds me to focus on my current benchmarks and to create goals to improve my current metrics. Basically, start where you are and try to improve by X%.

text: How do you approach partners about cross-promoting content? Has this worked well for anyone in the past as a way to reach new audiences? I'm thinking of having my COO send warm intro emails to our service partners and promote their blog content in our newsletters and SM. Is this completely unorthodox? Or maybe would it would be better to secure guest hosts for webinars?

text: idk if this still happens, but in the early days of HubSpot, agencies in the HubSpot partner network could white label HubSpot content to bulk up their own content libraries. I'm not mentioning this because I think it's still a good tactic in 2020, only as an example of one company that has done this very well :slightly_smiling_face: We co-promote partner content frequently and vice-versa

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

We co-promote partner content frequently and vice-versa

text:
There are a few principles I've found around this...
1. Everyone wants to know "what's in it for me" so offering to do it first can be a great way to show goodwill.
2. Not everyone is a good partner. Brands that understand the importance of educational content and that everything doesn't have to be a sales pitch make the best partners for co- promotion.
3. Don't leave it at co-promotion for one item. If you went to the trouble of starting something for a piece of content, explore ways you could work on ongoing collaborative content.

elements.text: There are a few principles I've found around this...
Everyone wants to know "what's in it for me" so offering to do it first can be a great way to show goodwill.
Not everyone is a good partner. Brands that understand the importance of educational content and that everything doesn't have to be a sales pitch make the best partners for co- promotion.
Don't leave it at co-promotion for one item. If you went to the trouble of starting something for a piece of content, explore ways you could work on ongoing collaborative content.

text:
Hey Kisha! About 60% of our marketing revolves around partner co-marketing and it helps us generate loads of fresh leads and get in front of the right audience. 

We tend to start the relationship with an intro from our Partnerships Team or our head of Marketing reaches out directly. I then get introduced as the content lead. 

To hold the partner accountable (and if it's a gated asset) we won't share the leads with the partners until they complete the promotional requirements we set out at the start of the campaign. More recently, we have also done a lead match (eg if the partner brings in 50 leads, they'll get 50 new leads back). This usually encourages them to work harder on the promo side.

elements.text:
Hey Kisha! About 60% of our marketing revolves around partner co-marketing and it helps us generate loads of fresh leads and get in front of the right audience. 

We tend to start the relationship with an intro from our Partnerships Team or our head of Marketing reaches out directly. I then get introduced as the content lead. 

To hold the partner accountable (and if it's a gated asset) we won't share the leads with the partners until they complete the promotional requirements we set out at the start of the campaign. More recently, we have also done a lead match (eg if the partner brings in 50 leads, they'll get 50 new leads back). This usually encourages them to work harder on the promo side.
